Introduction

CNS tumors are the second most common pediatric malignancies after leukemia and the most common pediatric solid tumors.  The most frequent types of primary brain tumors in children differ in type and location from those in adults.  The general pathophysiology, epidemiology/risk factors, clinical presentation, diagnosis, and management of primary brain tumors are discussed in more detail in a separate article.

Pathophysiology



Brain tumors can be classified according to their cell type of origin.  The brain is composed of 2 major cell types:  neurons and glial cells.  Neurons, which transmit information throughout the brain using electrical signals and chemical messengers, rarely form tumors.  Tumors more commonly originate from glial cells, which significantly outnumber neurons and normally provide support to maintain the health of the nervous system.  There are 3 main types of glial cells:



  • Astrocytes, the most common glial cell, help regulate the environment around neurons, contribute to nutrient exchange, and play a role in maintaining the blood-brain barrier.
  • Oligodendrocytes produce myelin, a fatty substance that insulates nerve fibers and allows for faster signal transmission.
  • Ependymal cells line the ventricles, fluid-filled cavities within the brain and spinal cord and are involved in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) production.


Gliomas, one of the most common types of primary brain tumor, originate from these glial cell populations (eg, astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas, ependymomas).  Tumors can also arise from the meninges (eg, meningioma) or from other cell types (eg, pituitary gland, pineal gland, embryonic origin).

Adult brain tumors



Commonly encountered adult brain tumors include:



  • Glioblastomas (eg, high-grade astrocytomas)
  • Oligodendrogliomas
  • Meningiomas
  • Schwannomas
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Primary CNS lymphoma


These are discussed in more detail in a separate dedicated article.

Pediatric brain tumors



Commonly encountered pediatric brain tumors include:



  • Pilocytic astrocytomas
  • Ependymomas
  • Medulloblastomas
  • Craniopharyngiomas
  • Pineal gland tumors
  • Choroid plexus papillomas

Pilocytic astrocytoma



Pilocytic astrocytomas are a type of low-grade astrocytoma and the most common childhood brain tumor.  Similar to adult astrocytoma, these are typically slow-growing and benign, causing symptoms to develop over many months.



  • Location:  They typically arise infratentorially, specifically within the cerebellum (eg, cerebellar astrocytoma).
  • Pathology:  Microscopic examination frequently shows a well-circumscribed tumor containing bipolar astrocytes with ovoid nuclei and hair-like (piloid) processes.  These processes contain glial fibrillary acidic protein, indicative of glial lineage.  Proteinaceous, eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions with a corkscrew appearance (ie, Rosenthal fibers (
    image 1
    )) and eosinophilic granular bodies (thought to be derived from lysosomes) are also often present.
  • Clinical features:  Because they typically arise within the cerebellum, they often present with symptoms of cerebellar dysfunction, such as ataxia.  They can also cause obstructive hydrocephalus (from obstruction of the 4th ventricle) leading to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • Radiologic features:  Pilocytic astrocytomas typically appear as well-circumscribed mass with an enhancing mural nodule and surrounding cystic components on MRI (
    image 2
    ).


In children with pilocytic astrocytoma, the prognosis is usually good, and surgical resection is often curative.

Ependymoma



Ependymomas originate from ependymal cells, which line the ventricles (fluid-filled cavities) within the brain.



  • Location:  These tumors can occur in any part of the ventricular system throughout the brain and spinal cord; the most common locations are within the posterior fossa in the fourth ventricle or in the spinal cord.
  • Pathology:  Histopathologic examination typically shows ependymal cells arranged around a central blood vessel (ie, perivascular pseudorosette (
    image 3
    )).
  • Clinical features:  Ependymomas cause symptoms related to their location in the ventricular system.  Ependymomas in the fourth ventricle can cause hydrocephalus (obstructed CSF flow) and increased ICP, leading to headaches, papilledema, and cranial nerve deficits.
  • Radiologic features:  Ependymomas can appear on MRI as hyperintense (on T2/FLAIR) cystic lesions with heterogeneous contrast enhancement.  Dilated ventricles can be seen with ependymomas that cause obstructed CSF flow.

Medulloblastoma



Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor arising from primitive neuroectodermal tissue (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  It is the most common malignant brain tumor in children.



  • Location:  Medulloblastomas arise in the posterior fossa (back lower part of the brain) in the cerebellum.
  • Pathology:  Histopathologic examination shows an embryonal tumor composed of sheets of small cells with round, hyperchromatic basophilic (ie, blue) nuclei and minimal cytoplasm.  The cells may be arranged around a central core of neuronal processes (ie, neuropil), forming Homer-Wright rosettes (
    image 4
    ).  Numerous mitotic figures are often present.
  • Clinical features:  Most patients with medulloblastoma have signs and symptoms that develop over weeks to months.  Medulloblastomas that occur in the vermis (eg, midline) of the cerebellum, which coordinates balance and gait, classically present with truncal or gait ataxia (eg, wide-based gait); involvement of more lateral portions of the cerebellum may cause problems with limb coordination, such as dysmetria and intention tremor.  Given the proximity to the fourth ventricle, medulloblastoma can also cause obstructive hydrocephalus with symptoms of increased ICP (eg, nighttime or early morning headaches, vomiting) (
    figure 1
    ).
  • Radiologic features:  Medulloblastomas typically appear as midline masses in the posterior fossa, with heterogeneous contrast enhancement causing obstructive hydrocephalus on MRI (
    image 5
    ).


Medulloblastomas have the potential for leptomeningeal spread through the CSF and are treated aggressively with surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.

Craniopharyngioma



Craniopharyngioma is a benign, slow-growing tumor arising from the epithelial remnants of Rathke pouch within the pituitary stalk (

figure 2
).



  • Location:  The mass is usually located in the suprasellar region adjacent to the optic chiasm and pituitary stalk.  It can compress the optic chiasm and hypothalamus.
  • Pathology:  Adamantinomatous craniopharyngiomas most often present as benign suprasellar tumors in children and appear as cords/nests of palisading squamous epithelium with areas of lamellar "wet" keratin under light microscopy (
    image 6
    ).
  • Clinical features:  Because of their slow growth, craniopharyngiomas often cause subtle symptoms for years before diagnosis.  Given their location, they can cause a variety of different symptoms:
    • Compression of the optic chiasm can lead to visual field deficits, including bitemporal hemianopsia (eg, loss of peripheral vision) (
      image 7
      ).
    • Pituitary stalk compression often causes panhypopituitarism, which most commonly manifests as growth failure due to TSH or growth hormone deficiency.  In addition, hypogonadism from LH and FSH deficiency may cause pubertal delay (eg, no breast development by age 12 in girls).  Arginine vasopressin deficiency (central diabetes insipidus) due to antidiuretic hormone deficiency and adrenal insufficiency due to corticotropin deficiency may also occur.
    • Compression of the third ventricle can lead to obstructive hydrocephalus, causing symptoms of increased ICP (eg, headaches, papilledema)
  • Radiologic features:  Craniopharyngiomas typically appear on neuroimaging as sellar or suprasellar masses with cystic and solid components with calcification (
    image 8
    ).  They may show heterogeneous enhancement.


Craniopharyngiomas are typically treated with surgery and/or radiation therapy (

).  The prognosis is variable, but many patients experience complications related to the location of the tumor (eg, endocrine issues or visual deficits).

Pineal gland tumors



The pineal gland is an endocrine gland within the CNS that modulates circadian rhythms by secreting melatonin in response to darkness or sympathetic stimulation.  Pineal gland tumors typically affect children (usually boys) up to age 14.  The most common pineal mass is a germinoma, a midline malignant tumor thought to arise from embryonic germ cells.



  • Location:  The pineal gland is a midline structure located dorsal to the superior colliculus in the midbrain and between the thalamic bodies (
    figure 3
    ).
  • Pathology:  The histopathology of pineal gland tumors depends on the type of mass (eg, type of germinoma).
  • Clinical features (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  Pineal gland masses often block CSF flow in the cerebral aqueduct, causing obstructive hydrocephalus, resulting in the classic symptoms of increased ICP (eg, papilledema, headache, nausea and vomiting).  Patients also classically have Parinaud syndrome (dorsal midbrain syndrome), which is characterized by:
    • Limitation of upward gaze with downward gaze preference (ie, setting sun sign) due to compression of the vertical gaze center (medial longitudinal fasciculus)
    • Light-near dissociation (ie, pseudoâ€“Argyll Robertson pupil):  pupils reactive to accommodation but not to light due to the disruption of dorsal optic tract fibers traveling to the Edinger-Westphal nuclei
    • Convergence retraction nystagmus (ie, nystagmus and retraction of the globe with upward gaze) and bilateral eyelid retraction (ie, Collier sign) due to disruption of the inhibitory fibers to the nucleus of the third nerve (affecting the rectus muscles and levator palpebrae)
    • Ataxia due to compression of the superior cerebellar peduncle
  • Radiologic features:  Neuroimaging usually shows a contrast-enhancing mass in the pineal gland, often causing obstructive hydrocephalus (
    image 9
    ).

Choroid plexus papilloma



The choroid plexus, a highly vascular neuroepithelial tissue found within the ventricles, produces CSF.  Most common in infants age <2, choroid plexus papilloma is a rare, slow-growing, benign overgrowth of the choroid plexus that results in increased CSF production.



  • Location:  These tumors usually occur in the lateral ventricles (eg, supratentorial).
  • Pathology:  On light microscopy, choroid plexus papillomas typically have a uniform population of choroid plexus cells.
  • Clinical presentation:  In infants, the accumulation of excess CSF produced by the tumor (ie, hydrocephalus) causes enlarging head circumference and signs of ICP (eg, bulging fontanelle, irritability, vomiting).  Developmental delay is also common.  Headaches can occur in older children and adults with this tumor.  With increasing tumor size, obstruction of CSF flow can occur, resulting in acutely increased ICP.
  • Radiologic features:  Head ultrasonography can be performed in infants and typically reveals enlarged ventricles with an intraventricular mass.  MRI confirms the diagnosis with a large, contrast-enhancing mass.


The treatment for a large or symptomatic choroid plexus papilloma is resection, and recurrence is rare.
